bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James P. Leake, December 3, 1946

div1.p: Hench describes his yellow fever research and inquires if the National Institute of Health possesses any letters related to the Reed experiments. He also discusses his attempts to memorialize Camp Lazear and solicits advice on gaining support for the project.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James P. Leake, December 3, 1946
div1.opener:
December 3, 1946
Dr. J. P. Leake
NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF HEALTH
Bethesda, Maryland
My dear Doctor Leake:
div1.p:
Our mutual friend, Dick Hewitt of our Editorial Department here,
knows of my considerable interest in the work of Walter Reed and his
associates. For some years, I have been collecting date thereon in prepara-
tion for a book. I have been extremely fortunate--the Reed family and
the Lazear family have made me the repository of all their letters, et
cetera. Just last week I was in Washington and had dinner with General Reed
and his sister, Blossom. The next day I visited Mrs. Walter Reed, who
is still living in Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania--almost ninety-one
years of age. While in Washington, I also had a pleasant day with
Mrs. G. O. Gawne, who was a first cousin of Doctor Lazear. This summer, in
California, I visited Lazear's son and daughter, having previously visited
his widow (who died in February). Some important letters of Reed and his
colleagues were given away by the family and others, of course, the family
never had. If you have any such letters that I could have photostat
copies of, or at least copies, I would be most happy to be permitted to
have them and would be glad to pay whatever expense is required to copy
them. By separate post I am sending you a reprint of mine on the subject.

Incidentally, we have discovered the lost Camp Lazear with
building No. 1 in which Reed did the famous experiments. You will find a
picture of it in the reprint. I have long hoped to start a campaign to
preserve the little building by erecting over it a small museum. The
Mayo Clinic is back of me in this venture--also the Walter Reed Memorial
Association. Can you give me any advice on how to go about such a cam-
paign? Do you think that the United States Public Health Association
would help me in the venture, either as an organization or through its
individual members? The Fiftieth Anniversary of the Conquest of Yellow
Fever will be in 1950. Wouldn't it be a grand thing if, in connection
therewith, a Cuban--American medical museum could have been erected on the
site of Camp Lazear?
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
